Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: An urgent directive from the coordinator outlines mandatory procedures that must be followed to avoid shutting down the service.
Story: I stared at my phone, my brother’s text lighting up the screen: “Hey, are you coming to the movie tonight? Everyone’s counting on you.” I’d promised him I’d be there, and I knew how much it meant—he’d been trying to include me more, to rebuild the closeness we’d lost over the years. But just as I was about to reply, an email from the volunteer coordinator popped up. The subject line read: “URGENT: Mandatory Procedures—Immediate Action Required.” The message was clear: if we didn’t follow the new guidelines tonight, the service we’d worked so hard to build could be shut down. I could almost hear the coordinator’s voice in my head, reminding me of my responsibility to the team and the people we serve. My brother’s expectation for me to show up and be present clashed painfully with the coordinator’s demand for my commitment. My chest tightened as I weighed the disappointment in my brother’s eyes against the trust my team placed in me. I sat frozen, torn between two worlds, feeling the pressure of both roles pressing in from all sides.
